title: Gabon - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: On 12 January 2021, workers of the Gabonese Shippers Council demonstrated in Owendo neighborhood of Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) against what they termed 'non-orthodox practices' in the management of the Council. [size=no report]

On 23 December 2020, about 15 MPs demonstrated at the National Assembly in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) against the revision of the Constitution that was on the agenda of a parliamentary debate the same day. [size=about 15]

On 7 December 2020, students of Omar Bongo University demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their scholarship arrears. The gendarmerie forces intervened to disperse them. [size=no report]
On 30 November 2020, health workers demonstrated in front of a hospital in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of a month arrears of their bonuses. [size=no report]

On 24 November 2020, students of the Omar-Bongo University demonstrated for the second day in a row, in Oloumi neighborhood of Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) against a delay in the payment of their scholarships. [size=no report]

On 23 November 2020, students of the Omar-Bongo University demonstrated in Oloumi neighborhood of Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) against a delay in the payment of their scholarships. [size=no report]

On 2 November 2020, students demonstrated at the USTM university of Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the resumption of classes that were halted due to the coronavirus pandemic. They barricaded the entrance of their university. [size=no report]

On 25 October 2020, Christians gathered at the Saint Charles Lwanga church of Oyem town (Ntem, Woleu-Ntem) in an attempt to celebrate mass as a protest against the prolonged restriction of gatherings due to coronavirus. The police fired sound grenades to disperse them. [size=no report]

On 7 October 2020, members of the national forest guards union demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their bonuses. They erected barricades at the entrance of the Ministry of Water and Forests. [size=no report]
Gabon Actu; Gabon Media Times; Gabo News

On 1 September 2020, about 50 forest guards demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their corporation allowances. The gendarmerie forces fired tear gas to disperse them, to which they replied with stones. Several were arrested, and 5 others injured. [size=about 50]

On 10 August 2020, former employees of the Gabon Press Agency demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Finance in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their dismissal allocations. [size=no report]
On 27 July 2020, teachers demonstrated in Owendo town (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of salary arrears. They erected barricades in front of they high school. [size=no report]

Around 23 July 2020 (as reported), residents captured one suspected robber and severely beat him up before handing him to the police in Nzeng-Ayong neighbourhood of Libreville city (Komoh-Mondah, Estuaire). [size=no report]

On 12 July 2020, a group of taxi drivers demonstrated in Port Gentil town (Bendje, Ogooue-Maritime) against abuses by security forces during the enforcement of the anti-coronavirus measures. The security forces (assumed Police Forces) reportedly arrested some of the demonstrators. [size=no report]

On 2 July 2020, members the Mining Ministry union clashed with the security guards (assumed Police Forces) of the minister in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) as they attempted to force their way to see the minister over concerns about mining royalties. Several people were injured. [size=at least several]

On 26 June 2020, students of the national teachers' school demonstrated for the second day in a row, in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their scholarships arrears. They erected barricades and burnt tires in front of their school. The security forces (assumed Police Forces) intervened to disperse them. [size=no report]

On 25 June 2020, more than a hundred students demonstrated in Masuku neighbourhood of Franceville town (Passa, Haut-Ogooue) against a vote at the National Assembly to decriminalize homosexuality. [size=more than a hundred]

On 25 June 2020, students of the national teachers' school demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their scholarships arrears. They disrupted ongoing courses and erected barricades to block the schools entry. [size=no report]

On 24 June 2020, tens of citizens demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) against a vote at the National Assembly to decriminalize homosexuality. The police forces intervened to disperse the demonstrators. 4 were arrested. [size=tens]

On 31 May 2020, villagers repelled the prefect of the Djouori-Agnili division who was bringing food support to Kabaga village, near Bongoville (Djouori-Agnili, Haut-Ogooue), in the context of counter coronavirus state support. They destroyed his gifts and threw it against his car. This was reportedly a reaction to the recent death of an influential local politician in prison. [size=no report]
Around 28 May 2020 (week of), the military forces severely beat up and injured two people in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire), for violating the counter coronavirus curfew.

On 27 May 2020, several public workers demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the regularisation of their administrative situation. The security forces fired tear gas to disperse them. One labour union leader was arrested. [size=several]
On 4 May 2020, teachers demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Education in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their salaries. [size=no report]
On 2 May 2020, residents captured and beat one suspected thief to death in Port Gentil town (Bendje, Ogooue-Maritime). [size=no report]

On 30 April 2020, unidentified individuals burnt the tribune of honour of the Engong Stadium in Oyem town (Ntem, Woleu-Ntem), and shared the video on the social media. The reason of this incident was not reported.

On 20 April 2020, residents erected barricades and blocked a main road as they demonstrated in Ntoum commune of Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire). They claimed that the government's distribution of food vouchers during the coronavirus lockdown was not well organised, and many residents were not taken into account. Security forces (assumed Police Forces) made use of tear gas to disperse them. One woman was reportedly injured. [size=no report]

On 17 April 2020 (or around), police intervened as residents demonstrated in Ntoum commune of Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire). They claimed that the government's distribution of food vouchers during the coronavirus lockdown was not well organised, and many residents were not taken into account. [size=no report]

On 30 March 2020, a group of taxi drivers demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) against what they describe as racketeering by security forces reportedly facilitated by coronavirus related measures. [size=no report]

On 9 March 2020, students of the national health institute blocked the entrance of their school in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) as they demonstrated to demand the payment of their scholarships. [size=no report]
On 7 March 2020, in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) the government of Gabon announced the 'temporary' closure the borders with Cameroon due to the coronavirus.

On 3 March 2020, locals seized transport equipment of an oil company operating in Lambarene town (Ogooue et Lacs, Moyen-Ogooue), as they demonstrated to demand a better redistribution of oil industry incomes. [size=no report]

On 5 Feb. 2020, members of the Dynamique Unitaire labour union staged a protest in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) against the government's austerity measures. The security forces [coded: Police Forces] intervened and arrested several protesters. [size=no report]

On 28 Jan. 2020 (or around), the police forces arrested 210 people suspected to be linked to the recent violent demonstrations that resulted in the death of 2 people in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire), after the rumours of children kidnappings.
Gabon Media Times; Africa 1; AFP; Gabon Actu; Gabo News

On 24 Jan. 2020, the population of PK9 area of Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) erected barricades and burnt tires as they were demonstrating against a wave of abduction of children (denied by Gabonese authorities). They clashed with the police and Gendarmerie forces who made use of tear gas. One person was burnt to death, and one other was beaten and injured, and later died of his wounds. A woman was killed by a stray bullet. (total of 3 fatalities). [size=no report]

On 23 Jan. 2020, the population of PK7 area of Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) erected barricades and burnt tires as they were demonstrating against an attempted abduction of a boy. The police forces intervened to remove the barricades and stop the fires. [size=no report]
On 10 January 2020, a group of students protested in Owendo town (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) against a reform of the baccalaureate exam. [size=no report]
Labour Group (Gabon); SOGATRA: Gabonese Transport Society

On 8 January 2020, a group of retired workers of Gabonese transport company staged a protest in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their retiring allowance. [size=no report]

On 2 December 2019, the police forces arrested the former Chief of Staff of Gabonese President, as well as the former Minister of Water and Energy, and former Oil Minister, in Libreville (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire). This occurred shortly after their dismissal from the government. They are accused of corruption.

On 21 November 2019, around twenty Gabonese government officials, including the government spokesman, were arrested in the city of Libreville (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) in the context of an anti-corruption investigation.

On November 18, 2019, the populations of Mimongo town (Ogoulou, Ngounie), blocked access to administration offices and erected roadblock as they demonstrated to demand better living conditions. [size=no report]
On November 5, 2019, the workers of Averda Company protested in Libreville, to demand the payment of 3 month salary arears. [size=no reports]
On October 25, 2019, the populations of Libreville staged a peaceful protest against the rape of a teeneager by a known businessman. [size=tens]
MPDRR: Patriotic and Democratic Movement for the Refoundation of the Republic
08 August. Police forces arrested Jean-Francois Ntoutoume Emane, the former Prime Minister and opposition party leader of MPDRR, and two of his sons in the Tahiti area of north Libreville.
15 July. Police arrested the leader of the FPG party, Gerard Ella Nguema, before a planned political march in Libreville.
Police Forces of Gabon (2009-) Prison Guards
21 June. Police forces tortured a civilian to death in a Franceville, Passa prison.

11 June. Students demonstrated in Libreville at University of Omar Bongo to demand scholarships, shutting down exams. Gendarme forces intervened to disrupt the demonstration, with reports of clashes and violence with students. [size=no report]

07 June. Students riot against police forces with rocks and other projectiles at Omar Bongo University in Libreville over distribution of scholarship funds. Police forces use tear gas to disperse the riot. [size=no report]
19 April. A group of pensioners protest in Libreville at the office of CNSS over payment of their pensions. [size=no report]
15 April. Striking teachers protest in Libreville of Komo-Mondah demanding better wages. [size=no report]
09 April. Students continue to protest in Libreville over the reduction of university grant funding. Police dispersed the demonstration. [size=thousands]
09 April. Students protest in Bitam over the reduction of university grant funding. Some students were injured as they clashed with police who fired teargas [size=thousands]
09 April. Students protest in Oyem over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
09 April. Students protest in Bitam over the reduction of university grant funding. Some students were injured as they clashed with police who fired teargas [size=thousands]
09 April. Students protest in Tchibanga over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
09 April. Students protest in Lambarene over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Libreville over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Bitam over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Oyem over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Mouila over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Tchibanga over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Lambarene over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Franceville over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Moanda over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Port Gentil over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
21 March. Employees of the Cleaning and Hygiene Company protest in Port Gentil of Bendje over salaries. [size=no report]
11 March. Dock workers in Owendo of Komo-Mondah protest against the poor working conditions and employment security of the Bollore firm. [size=no report]

07 March. During a government meeting with teachers' unions in Libreville, teachers gather outside the building and prevent the government ministers and trade union members from leaving. [size=no report]
06 March. Teachers protest by arranging a sit-in in front of the prime minister's office in Libreville, demanding years of unpaid salaries. [size=no report]
01 March. Transport workers from the National Regional Transport Company protest near the airport in Libreville over months of unpaid wages. [size=no report]
PSI: Tax Personnel Syndicate; Labour Group (Gabon)
28 February. Several unions strike and demonstrate in Owendo demanding the release of a study on finance authorities. Demonstrators block the port in Owendo. [size=no report]
06 February. Gabon teachers protest in front of Sainte Marie Cathedral in Libreville over salaries for three days. Police intervene each day to disperse the demonstration.
05 February. Gabon teachers protest in front of Sainte Marie Cathedral in Libreville over salaries for three days. Police intervene each day to disperse the demonstration.
04 February. Gabon teachers protest in front of Sainte Marie Cathedral in Libreville over salaries for three days. Police intervene each day to disperse the demonstration.
03 February. Protesters block streets in Lamarene against the ethnic imbalance in municipal posts, favouring the Galois and Merie ethnic groups over the Akele.

30 January. Heavily armed police in 3 trucks raid Razel area of Owendo, a town on the outskirts of Libreville, breaking into and raiding homes, schools, churches and shops as well as making arrests and firing rounds at civilians.

Week of January 21. Students demand payment of their scholarships from the National Institute of Health and Social Action Training, demonstrating at the entrance of the building for a week (coded as 2 events)

21 January. Three members of the opposition party group, National Union, are arrested by Gabon police in Libreville in connection with the January 7th coup d'etat. The three men are Firmin Ollo (current president of the youth movement of the National Union), Ballack Obame (a former student leader of National Union) and Mathurin Ovono (also a former student leader). They are later released on January 23.

Week of January 21. Students demand payment of their scholarships from the National Institute of Health and Social Action Training, demonstrating at the entrance of the building for a week (coded as 2 events)
SNLS: National Society for Social Housing
17 January. SNLS workers go on strike and protest in Libreville over jobs after the SNLS merged into the National Real Estate Company (SNI).
SOGATRA: Gabonese Transport Society; Labour Group (Gabon)
11 January. Agents of SOGATRA protest in front of Tresor buildings in Libreville over salary disputes.
SNLS: National Company of Social Housing
11 January. SNLS employees protest in Libreville by blocking access to their office over salary disputes.

07 January. Rioters burn tires, clash with police and set fire to a car in Libreville in a neighborhood near the radio station in support of the attempted coup. Rioters were dispersed by police using tear gas.
Mutiny of Military Forces of Gabon (2009-)

07 January. After a group of 6 soldiers led by Lieutenant Ondo Obiang Kelly attempt a coup in Libreville by taking over the state radio station, military forces launch an assault against the radio station, killing 2 and arresting others involved.
Mutiny of Military Forces of Gabon (2009-)

07 January. A group of 6 soldiers led by Lieutenant Ondo Obiang Kelly, the deputy commander of the Republican Guard, attempt a coup in Libreville by taking over the state radio station, chasing gendarmes and holding journalists hostage. Military forces take back the radio station from soldiers involved in the coup hours later, killing 2 and arresting others involved. Unknown number of 'Gendarmes neutralized' coded as 3.
SOGATRA: Gabonese Transport Society; Labour Group (Gabon)
December 27. Members of SOGATRA public transport service riot over salaries and kidnap the transport minister, Justin Ndoudangoye, in Libreville. The minister was released on the same day.

December 18. Police prevent a Dynamic Union protest against government austerity measures. Heavy police presence blocked roads, exit from vehicles and marching by protesters in Libreville near Rond point de la democratie.
11-14 December. CESE members protest, demanding the resignation of Rene Ndemezo'o Obiang, the office chair.
11-14 December. CESE members protest, demanding the resignation of Rene Ndemezo'o Obiang, the office chair.
11-14 December. CESE members protest, demanding the resignation of Rene Ndemezo'o Obiang, the office chair.
11-14 December. CESE members protest, demanding the resignation of Rene Ndemezo'o Obiang, the office chair.

10 December. The trade union confederation Dynamique Unitaire (DU) launched a three day national general strike to protest over economic impacts of austerity programs and demand the resignation of the President of the Constitutional Court, Marie-Madeleine Mborantsuo, who, in the absence of the head of the The State, modified the Constitution

26 November. Officers of the General Directorate of the National Center for University Works barricaded the access of the Ministry of Higher Education in Libreville to protest over non-payment of salaries

On Nov 23 a hundred Gabonese protested in Libreville against the 'manipulation of the constitution', amended by the Constitutional Court to overcome the absence of President Ali Bongo, hospitalized for a month in Riyadh.
28 October. A group protests for polio awareness along the seafront in Libreville.
On 14 August, a greek tanker carrying 17 Georgian sailors was possibly attacked and the sailors kidnapped by pirates in Gabonese waters.

SYNAPS: National Union of Health Personnel; SYNAGREF: National Union of Clerks; SENA: National Education Union; SYNAMONPS: National Union of Non-Permanent Health Workers; SYNACNAMGS: National Union of the National Health Insurance and Social Security Fund; Teachers (Gabon); Health Workers (Gabon)

On 27 July, the National Union of Clerks (Synagref); the National Education Union (Sena), the National Union of Non-permanent Health Workers (Synamonps); the National Union of the National Health Insurance and Social Security Fund (Synacnamgs) and the National Union of Health Workers (Synaps) gathered to protest against government austerity measures.
On 23 July, angry people from Gamba in the province of Ogooue-Maritime barricaded roads and streets to denounce the prevailing unemployment affecting the small oil town.
SYNAFOPRA: National Union of the Agents of the Ministry of Civil Service and Administrative Reform; NAR: New Republican Alliance

On 11 July, several organizations of the Gabonese civil society and political personalities including SYNAFOPRA and NAR in Awendje in the 4th arrondissement of Libreville, protested against the austerity measures taken by the Council of Ministers on June 21, which they say are aimed more at 'making Gabonese workers more precarious'.
Property destruction: on 16 June, the home of Fefe Onanga, opposition and political activist was set on fire in an arson attack in the Grand village district of Port-Gentil. No injuries reported.
Police Forces of Gabon (2009-) Prison Guards
On 5 June, prisoners in the central prison of Franceville in Haut-Ogooue, launched an assault on prison guards in protest at the non-delivery of food rations for several days.

Property destruction: on 3 June, the HQ of former presidential candidate, Jean Ping, was vandalised in Bas-de-Gue-Gue in the first arrondissement of Libreville reportedly by supporters of President Ali Bongo.
Military Forces of Gabon (2009-) Republican Guard
On 28 May, shots were fired by an unknown group wounding a Republican Guard agent while he was on a surveillance mission in the 1st district of Libreville.
On 23 May, students from the Owendo Institute of Technology staged a sit-in outside the Gabonese National Scholarship Agency over the 9-month suspension of their scholarships.
On 22 May, teachers at the Ecole Nationale Superieure in the 1st arrondissement of Libreville went on strike to demand 3 years of unpaid leave. They blocked access to the school.
On 14 May, students protested in the 5th arrondissement of Libreville outside BICIG Oloumi against the non-payment of their scholarships since 2017. 28 were arrested by police forces.
On 12 May, protesters held demonstrations to demand the release of Blaise Wada in Bakoumba.
On 1 May (Labour Day), agents of Radio Gabon and Gabon Televisions chant slogans hostile to the Minister of Communication, Alain Claude Bilie-By-Nze in Libreville.

Non-violent activity: on 30 April, the constitutional court dissolved the national parliament and called for the government to step down after its failure to organise legislative elections. On 1 May, the government resigned and on 4 May, a new interim government was installed.
Around 25 April, in Sotega district of Libreville, a police officer beat a woman over the head during an altercation between the members of the two families as part of a land dispute.
SNEC: National Union of Teachers and Researchers
On 13 April, the National Union of Teaching Researchers (SNEC) at the Omar Bongo University picketed after suspending activity on 9 March over lack of payment.
On 3 April, trainee teachers held a sit-in on the Ministry of Education premises. They were violently dispersed by security forces and several arrested. No reported injuries.
On 27 March, several teachers barricaded the entrance to the Ministry of Education and observed a sit-in over their financial situation. Four were arrested.
Taxi drivers in Libreville barricaded the main highways to protest the increase in fuel prices.
Clashes broke out between the police and taxi drivers protesting the increase in fuel prices in Bikele.
A Nigerien man attacked 2 Danish tourists in a market in Libreville. He claims to have attacked them in retaliation for US attacks on Muslims.
Students and police officers clashed in the outskirts of Libreville. Students protesting the increase in university fees broke windows and fought the police.
Students at the Omar Bongo University are preventing other students from enrolling, in order to protest the increase in enrollment fees.
36 Jean Ping supporters were arrested at a demonstration in Libreville.
Supporters of opposition leader, Jean Ping, protested in Libreville to commemorate the anniversary of the disputed election. The police dispersed them.
Supporters of opposition leader, Jean Ping, protested in Port-Gentil to commemorate the anniversary of the disputed election. The police dispersed them.

A riot control vehicle was parked outside the police headquarters in Port Gentil, in anticipation of a show of strength from Jean Ping's supporters. It was doused in gasoline and set alight by unidentified assailants.
Several hundred supporters of Jean Ping attempted to welcome their leader at the airport, but were dispersed by the police, who fired teargas at the crowd. 2 people were injured.
People demonstrated to support president Ali Bongo after a report on air on Thursday shed light on his biased re-election.
Thousands of people in Port Gentil participated in a general strike and a protest against the high cost of living and the increasing unemployment.
LVDPG: Voice of the Gabonese People
Members of LVDPG attempted to hold a demonstration against the Gabonese government. The demonstration was prevented by the police, who arrested 20 activists.
Nearly 200 trade unionists were dispersed by the police from a May Day demonstration.
Students in Moanda (Haut-Ogooue) protested and marched to demand payment of their scholarships and an end to the ongoing teachers strike.
Students of the Agathe Obendze Technical High School in Franceville protested and marched in solidarity with students in other areas protesting against the government.
High school students protested in Libreville, Port Gentil and Kambarene (centre) to demand better studying conditions.
High school students protested in Libreville, Port Gentil and Kambarene (centre) to demand better studying conditions.

High school students protested in Libreville, Port Gentil and Kambarene (centre) to demand better studying conditions. Police intervened in the Port Gentil march and dispersed it using tear gas. Several students were reported injured.
High school students protested in Oyem to demand better studying conditions.
UFC: Union of Forces for Change
Many people are boycotting AFCON matches on the call of Jean Ping, the former opposition presidential candidate (UFC), to protest against the government over the outcome of recent elections.

Strikes: Unions decreed an unlimited general strike. Believing to be 'despised' by the government, unions in the education sector have decided to return to unlimited general strike two weeks after the launch of a first warning strike.

Suspected arsonists started a fire in the Potos market of Franceville destroying a significant part of it. Youths from the area looted goods from the area during the disorder created by the flames. It is believed the fire was related to the regions stance during recent post-election unrest.
As many as a thousand people marched in Libreville to support the re-election of President Bongo. The demonstrators were allegedly mostly young and were protected by the police.
UFC: Union of Forces for Change

A thousand supporters of opposition leader Jean Ping dressed in white marched Saturday in Libreville, in tribute to the victims of post-election violence that rocked Gabon after the presidential election of 27 August.
UFC: Union of Forces for Change
Opposition supporters gather outside Jean Pings headquarters in Libreville and hold a vigil for those killed in the anti-government protests.
Dozens of 'angry relatives' gathered outside the Libreville courthouse for news of their relations after rioting in Libreville following President Bongos re-election.
Rioting was reported in the Plein-Ciel area of Libreville, including violence and looting.

Rioters attacked Hausa and Muslim minority areas of Bitam following the re-election of President Bongo. A large warehouse of a food supplier and a thrift store were both burned down during the rioting, although no casualties were reported. Mosques and business owned by the Hausa/Muslim community in the areas were also targeted by molotov cocktail, stone and club wielding youths.
Continued protests and rioting were reported in Libreville over the weekend.
UFC: Union of Forces for Change
Military Forces of Gabon (2009-) Republican Guard

2 protesters were killed in overnight clashes between protesters and security forces in Libreville over the results of the election. Both were killed by gunshot, one by the Republican Guard as they fired tear gas and live rounds to disperse protesters; the other by unidentified assailants in a drive-by shooting.
In Oyem, a policeman was hospitalized after being shot in the head during ongoing unrest over the election. Official sources said the policeman came out if the coma on September 9.

In Port Gentil, some youths barricaded shops to prevent looting while others blocked roads and threw rocks at police, who responded with tear gas, during ongoing protests over the results of the election. At least one youth was reportedly killed by the security forces during the unrest in the Ngadi Ball area of the Beacon district of Port-Gentil.
UFC: Union of Forces for Change
Military Forces of Gabon (2009-) Republican Guard
Clashes continued between protesters demonstrating against the re-election of President Bongo and security forces in te Nkemob district of Libreville.
Military Forces of Gabon (2009-) Republican Guard
UFC: Union of Forces for Change

Police and Republican Guard personnel opened fire on the campaign headqaurters of presidential candidate Jean Ping, killing 2 and injuring more than a dozen. One of those injured later died in hospital according to a Red Cross worker. They later arrested dozens of members of the UPC in the building. Jean Ping also claimed they ransacked the building after storming it.
Military Forces of Gabon (2009-) Republican Guard
UFC: Union of Forces for Change

Arrests: 27 opposition and civil society leaders were arrested outside Pings campaign HQ after a security forces raid on the building. The opposition leaders were later freed by the security forces on Aug.2. Security forces have detained between 600-800 people in Libreville in relation to the violent protests following the re-election of President Bongo.
UFC: Union of Forces for Change

Supporters of Gabonese presidential candidate Jean Ping clashed with security forces in Libreville following the declaration that President Bongo had won the presidential elections. Several hundred protesters attempted to storm the offices of the election commission but were repulsed by police using tear gas and stun grenades. The demonstrators elswhere in the city set the parliament buildings on fire, while there were reports of looting, vandalism and arson. Police allegedly also opened fire on protesters at one point, wounding at least 6. Tanks were also reportedly present during the events. At least 1 person was killed during the violence.

Arrests: Security forces have detained as many as 200-300 people outside the capital (where at least 600 were arrested) in relation to the violent protests following the re-election of President Bongo.

Property destruction: The offices of Radio-Television Nazareth (RTN) were set on fire 'by hooded and heavily armed agents of the security forces'. Attacks have also been reported against the news agency Tele Plus.
The news station RTN reported attacks against its offices.
Hundreds protested President Ali Bongos candidacy for re-election. Security forces violently charged at demonstrators, injuring 11 while 2 security forces were also seriously injured.

Spontaneus demonstration led by the opposition after the speech of Ali Bongo for marking the official filing of his application at the election on August 27. The police dispersed the crowd. According to the police was about 350/500 people, while according to the authorities 30 to 50.000 took the streets in protest.
Up to 26 people in custody, 5 of which arrested after throwing stones at the police on Saturday while 150 to 200 against opponents were demonstrating near the presidential meeting.
Judges held street protests against political appointments.
The Palace of Justice was closed as the National Judges Union protested against recent nominations to the Judicial Council.
Students protested to demand payment of scholarships and were dispersed by police, who reportedly used violence and teargas, causing injuries.
Students protested to demand payment of scholarships and were dispersed by police.
Police stopped protesters who were marching against police brutality.

Self-harm and psychological intervention: A young man set himself on fire in front of the police prefect to protest frequent 'police harassment' and confiscation of goods. He later died of his injuries. In response, protesters planned to march against police harassment, but they were banned.
Four were arrested for removing their clothing while protesting police violence.
Clashes between bank employee rioters and police.
UPG loyalists gather at the Research Directorate General building to demand justification for the arrest of former minister Mabiala. Police fired tear gas.
453 migrants from Senegal, Mali, Nigeria and Burkina Faso were expelled by Gabonese authorities, and human rights groups claim they were abused in the process. The government denies the claim.
Teachers at the Omar Bongo University went on strike to demand unpaid compensation and blocked the road into the university with their cars.

Crowds awaiting the delayed arrival of the remains of opposition leader Andre Mba Obame threw rocks at public buildings and torched market stalls. Police responded with batons and stun grenades and arrested at least three.
Crowds of mourners prevented the remains of opposition leader Andre Mba Obame from flying from Libreville to the town of Oyem.

Movement of forces: Police were deployed for added security following unrest in Libreville, at sites including the National Assembly, oil offices, and major intersections near the headquarters of the National Union party.
Opposition members rioted following the death of Mba Obame, setting fire to cars and buildlings, including the Embassy of Benin, and erecting barricades in Libreville.

The PDG organized a 'peace march' which culminated in a rally involving several political parties of the presidents coalition. Another march and rally was held by the United Opposition Front. A wall of police separated the two rallies.
Students marched to demand reestablishment of classes that have been cancelled due to teacher protests. Armed police blocked their route.
Dynamic Unit Union; Labour Group (Gabon); Government of Gabon (2009-)

Under the direction of Dynamique Unitaire, 3,000 public workers conducted a sit-in in front of the National Assembly and were dispersed by police using tear gas. They regrouped at the University Omar Bongo and announced their decision to continue the general strike that began in early February.
Students protested to demand the end of teacher strikes.
Hundreds of people gathered at a rally to mark the renewal of a general strike called by a union coalition at a Oulabou Martine public school in Libreville.
The Dynamic Unit [Dynamique unitaire] union protest outside the government administrative offices of Ogooue-Maritime. The demonstrators were eventually turned away by police.
SNEC: National Union of Teachers and Researchers

Public sector trade unionists, particularly educators, marched to the General Assembly to file a strike notice but were blocked by police forces. The strike was extended a month later, on 16 March, to demand wage increases.

A gang of around 200 - 350 youth attacked the home of opposition leader Jean Ping, throwing stones and lighting fires. Ping says the authorities paid the youth to assault his home and that police refused to intervene; it is unclear whether opposition supporters or the police ended the attack, detaining several people.
FUOPA: United Opposition Front for Change
Opposition party protesters held a silent march in support of France in light of the Charlie Hebdo attacks.
100 activists demonstrated in front of the French Embassy, accusing French media of spreading hate in Gabon, interefering in Gabonese affairs, and media bias.

At least one student was killed in clashes at an opposition rally, where police fired tear gas to disperse protesters demanding the resignation of the president. At least 20 were arrested in scuffles between police and demonstrators, while shops were looted and cars set on fire.
FUOPA: United Opposition Front for Change

Banned demonstrations against President Ali Bongo Ondimba erupted in violence between protestors and police, resulting in injuries, property damage, around 100 arrests, and between one and six deaths.

Protesters wanted to go into the courthouse in Libreville to file a complaint concerning the alleged falsification of President Bongo Ondimbas birth certificate. Police fired tear gas and bullets. No reported injuries.
March in streets of Port-Gentil to support for President Ondimba.
To support inter-Malian talks in Algiers, the Malian community in Gabon marched outside of the Malian embassy in Libreville.

Students from Omar Bongo University rioted outside of the Treasury in Libreville on Oct. 12, 13, and 14, demanding payment of grants. Rioters threw projectiles at police vehicles; police fired tear gas. No injuries reported.

Students from Omar Bongo University rioted outside of the Treasury in Libreville on Oct. 12, 13, and 14, demanding payment of grants. Rioters threw projectiles at police vehicles; police fired tear gas. No injuries reported.

Students from Omar Bongo University rioted outside of the Treasury in Libreville on Oct. 12, 13, and 14, demanding payment of grants. Rioters threw projectiles at police vehicles; police fired tear gas. No injuries reported.

University students, former members of the National Social Security Fund and teachers hold a hunger strike at St. Marys Cathedral in Libreville. Police evicted strikers at 3am on September 13. No serious injuries reported.
SAPAS: Independent Union of Social Affairs Workers
Staff at the Ministry of Social Affairs protest demonstrate against payment irregularities.
Students at Omar Bongo University throw stones at police. Police fire teargas to disperse the rioters.
Students protested at the National Commerce school in Port-Gentil, calling for payment of scholarships

Workers from the Public Works workers' syndicate (SYFO/TP) approached the provincial Public Works ministry in Ogooue-Ivindo, protesting the refusal to negotiate over workers' concerns after a 72-hour strike.

Students demonstrated in the streets of Libreville against reforms introduced by the Ministry of Education. Some demonstrators engaged in acts of vandalism. Police fired tear gas and several arrests were made. Reforms postponed as a result.

Many high school and college students took to the streets in Libreville between Wednesday and Friday in a walk to demand an end to the teachers strike which has disrupted classes from the beginning of the school year in October 2013. As a result, the Gabonese government has decided to close public schools on October 15th until further notice to maintain public order.

Many high school and college students took to the streets in Libreville between Wednesday and Friday in a walk to demand an end to the teachers strike which has disrupted classes from the beginning of the school year in October 2013.

Many high school and college students took to the streets in Libreville between Wednesday and Friday in a walk to demand an end to the teachers strike which has disrupted classes from the beginning of the school year in October 2013.
A riot erupted in Libreville prison as prisoners felt their hunger strike was going unnoticed. Gendarmes arrived as reinforcements and used tear gas. 2 inmates escaped.
Journalists begin a sit-in and hunger strike outside the Office of the Prime Minister over pay issues.

At Omar Bongo University students of the Faculty of Law and Economic Sciences broke windows and started fires in protest against high exam failure rates. Police used tear gas and five policemen were injured.
The police arrested thirty students who organized a peaceful march to demand scholarships.

Employees of Africa Clean staged a sit-in in front of their headquarters in Libreville. The staff demanded wage increases, increases in total premiums on risk, quality, tooling, cash, detoxification and housing assistance.
A Maltese-flagged tanker was attacked Monday afternoon by pirates off Cap Lopez, Port Gentil. Two days after the incident the ship and crew (24 Indians) were found.

Several primary and secondary school teachers protested Wednesday outside the office of Minister of National Education, Seraphim Moundounga. They demanded payment of the premium incentive for the teaching profession (Pife) that they have not benefitted from since 2010.
Some students who took part in the riot and protest earlier in May to protest against their banishement from the Baccalaureat exam, have started a hunger strikein front of the cathedral
Peaceful march to protest against the ritual crimes in Gabon
Rioting and road blocking by high school students against the decision of excluding the ones caught cheating from exams such as the 'baccalaureat
Protest from high school students against the decision of excluding the ones caught cheating from exams such as the 'baccalaureat'

Clashes have recently opposed, in Bakoumba city in the province of Upper Ogooue, rioters and the local branch of the police after they had arrested the youth who had closed the road that connects the city to the rest of Gabon.
The police used tear gas to disperse students protesting violently in the streets asking for classes to start again.
After the Omar Bongo University was paralyzed by a several months long strike, a peaceful march has been organised by both students and teachers.
Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
Agreement: A peace deal was reached between Bozizes administration and Seleka rebels, concluding peace talks in Gabon.
Government of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)

Agreement: Peace talks between 15 members of the Seleka rebel militia and CAR government began in Libreville. Several ministers of the 10 countries in the Economic Community of Central African States oversaw the negotiations.
Journalist Olivier Ndembi is interrogated by the General Directorate for Investigation regarding his research into the alleged involvement of Gabonese politicians in ritual killings
A gang armed with a hammer attacked the television station of Gabons main opposition leader Andre Mba Obame
Lagos, Nigeria: Unidentified gunmen today stormed a private television station owned by Gabons main opposition leader and burned down its transmitters
Violent confrontations between the police and protesters in Libreville
Nineteen students were arrested last week after trying to halt classes at the university. They were accused of disturbing the peace and held for four days before being released on bail.
Police forces of Gabon (2009-) arrest potential protesters opposing the New York Forum Africa, opening 8 June in Libreville.

Students threw stones at police and officers fired teargas to disperse them in a new bout of clashes Wednesday at Omar Bongo University in Gabons capital Libreville. The university has been the scene of violent protests by students demanding payment of scholarship funds.
The former head of state security and two others are arrested for plotting a coup.
Military forces fire tear gas to disperse opposition protesters supportive of Andre Mba Obame of the Gabonese Democratic Party (PDG). Thirty arrested, injuries reported.
Military forces fire tear gas to disperse opposition protesters supportive of Andre Mba Obame of the Gabonese Democratic Party (PDG). Thirty arrested, injuries reported.
Municipal workers carried the body of a dead colleague into Libreville city hall to protest an ongoing labor dispute.
Police injure 18 people who were protesting over non-payment of arrears and grants
Students from the Omar Bongo University protest the non-payment of federal executive grants from the government. Clashes with police, 18 injured when they attempt to intervene and disperse the crowd.
Police harass and beat supporters of rival parties
Frances consulate set on fire after Ali Bongo declared winner of pres election
police beat people protesting to hear presidential election results
Unidentified armed group attacked television station owned by a presidential candidate
Opposition parties march for the resignation of Ali Bongo from defence minister since he was running for th presidency. Police threw teargas at protesters
A journalist was beaten by soldiers inside the presidential compound. The journalist was taken to the intensive care unit.
Police used force against protesters who were demonstrating against the high cost of living in Gabon. A journalist was beaten for filming the violence.
Police forces harassed street vendors and beat at least one vendor. Police harassed the vendors to pay them money.
A Nigerian man was beaten to death by Gabon security forces which incited Nigerian market vendors to demonstrate against the abuse.
A Nigerian man was beaten to death by Gabon security forces which incited Nigerian market vendors to demonstrate against the abuse.
Demonstrators protested against the rising cost of living and Omar Bongos re-election. Protests were led by the UPG.

Protesters marched in the streets of Libreville after President Omar Bongo was announced winner of the Presidential elections. Bongo had been president of for seven terms. Police responded to the protest with batons and tear gas. At least ten people we
Protesters demonstrated outside the Pan-Ocean Energy production facility over the allocation of oil profits. Police forces killed two demonstrators.

After gendarmes killed two civilians during a protest in Lebamba on 2/9/04, citizens of Lembamba retaliated by killing two gendarmes. The military was called in for back up. Subsequently, 30 people were detained for the 9/9/04 killings.
Rioters erected barricades to demand the resumption of electricity to villages. Gendarmie killed two people while trying to quiet the protests.
Agreement: ANR and Chadian government signed a peace accord pledging an immediate ceasefire in the conflict zone and general amnesty for rebel soldiers and sympathizers in Gabon Thursday
An unidentified armed group attacked a ship captain and stole from the ship that was in port at Port Gentil.

Thirty women were beaten by an unidentified armed group hired by an unsuccessful presidential candidate. The group was hired to punish people who did not observe a protest to shut down the town (the protest was to denounce the re-election of Omar Bongo
Fisherman protested against the placement of an foreign invasive fish in the area which has caused other fish native to the area to die out.
Unemployed rioters set buildings and fuel stations on fire to protest high unemployment. Police intervened.
Unemployed rioters set buildings and fuel stations on fire to protest high unemployment. Police intervened.
Protesters were demonstrating against a strike by transport workers who had not been paid for three weeks.
Protesters were demonstrating against a strike by transport workers who had not been paid for three weeks.
Students and lecturers at Omar Bongo University protested for payments and better payment systems.
Police were in a shoot out with gang members responsible for the killing of Gabonese and Lebanese in Gabon. Fatalities: 2 gang members.
Soldiers were blamed for killing two people and wounding 11 for revenge for the death of a corporal the previous week.
Telecommunications employees protested the restructuring of their administration- fearing it would lead to privatization.
Students at Omar Bongo University protested being censored on state television.

Supporters of the PDG and CLR, rival parties that both support President Bongo, fought each other over polling organization. Fatalities: 4 people. It was not stated which side of the violence the deaths were on.
